is it still such a difficult problem to build high-quality conversational assistant and it comes down to a few
things one is that many of these published papers focus on just a single component of a larger problem so it
focuses just on reading comprehension or just on question answering they don't tell you how to string together all of
these components to prove to create a full conversational app and as
you are stringing together these different components you get a sort of compounding error effect where if you're
reading comprehension module doesn't fully understand what the user is trying to say it makes it very difficult for
the question/answer to then respond back with the answer that the user is expecting in addition many of these
papers are evaluated on standardized data sets and it can be very difficult
for you to build out a training data set that has the amount of data that exists
in these standardized data sets and so the state-of-the-art models that work well on large training data sizes may
not work well on your smaller data sets in addition the characteristics of these data sets may be different your
real-world data sets may have more noise or different types of noise than exists and the standardized data sets that
these papers are being evaluated on and so again the state-of-the-art models may not necessarily translate in accuracy to

the domain of your use case you can achieve higher accuracy more easily
because you can focus in on domain-specific knowledge and vocab however you also need your use case to

selecting the right use cases finding those cases that are both high accuracy
and strong value proposition so the
first set of data to be collected is domain specific metadata so there's
three sub categories of this the first is domain-specific vocabulary so if we
take these Starbucks coffee ordering use case as an example some of the
domain-specific vocabulary are things like Frappuccino macchiato venti
words that are very common in this domain but very rare outside of it also
there's words like tall which means something different in the Starbucks ordering domain than it does in general
English language and so by collecting large amounts of this domain vocabulary
you can tailor your models for the specific language and data the next
category is data for a structured knowledge base so this varies by use
case but it's essentially a structured data set of all of the domain world
knowledge that you need to fulfill a user's request so for the food ordering
use case this would be things like restaurant names menus and dishes
options etc and for like a music discovery use case it would be stuff
like song titles albums artists and a
lot of this data is often either publicly available and can be scraped or it can be consolidated VSM api's or may
be already available internally within your organization but it's generally something that you can compile
programmatically from what's already existing in addition to the structure
database in a lot of use cases you may need to query against a live API rather
than querying something like the knowledgebase which is updated less frequently so some
examples of where you would need a live API are things like if you need to know
that what the weather is right now or if you want to know what the inventory is versus a big product right now or if you
want to actually place a request like placing an order at a restaurant and these again are either publicly
available maybe available within your organization or you could have some sort of partnership with another organization to have access to their api's and in
addition to the domain metadata you also need to collect conversational data so
this is the actual natural language text of what a user would say something like please schedule a call at 4:00 p.m. in

need to collect labels for that text so these labels are corresponding to the

winterfell is a conference room name and a lot of times this data
unlike domain metadata it doesn't exist anywhere already so it's something that
we leverage crowdsourcing tools like Amazon Mechanical Turk CrowdFlower etc to generate both the natural language
queries themselves as well as the annotations and labels for those queries and it's important that the annotations
for these queries are very clean because if you don't have the clean label data
even the most advanced machine learning models won't perform perform well so in
order to ensure that these labels are clean we can do some sort of sanity checks where we have multiple different

um so for unsupervised learning do you

there's many components of building a conversational assistant that form a complex machine learning pipeline so
each one of these components is its own machine learning model that can be built leveraging open-source tool kits like
psychic learners tensorflow and at a high level the natural language
processor component is what extracts all of the important information from the query like what is these are intending
to do and what are the key words or phrases in that query that are needed to
complete the request and then the question answer and the dialogue manager then generate the response back to the
user and complete any requested actions and then if we are using a voice based
conversational assistant rather than a type or text-based one we additionally need two components the first is the
automatic speech recognition component which converts the audio into text and
then the text-to-speech component at the end which synthesizes the response text
back into speech so now I'll walk through each of the components in the
pipeline so if you have a voice assistant the first step is ASR automatic speech recognition and this in
and of itself is a very complex problem at a high level the components are from
the raw audio using acoustic features to extract some feature vectors and then
you have a phonetic model which takes these acoustic features as input and outputs a sequence of characters which
represents the sequence of phonemes in the audio and then there's a language model which takes the sequence of phonetic sounds and outputs the actual
understandable English language and that takes into account a general English English language assistance
six on what words or phrases are most commonly said so the cost of building an
ASR system from scratch if you don't already have an in-house solution especially one that is better than third
party ASR systems that are publicly available is incredibly high so in the
interests in the interest of time if you're starting out to building an
application and you don't already have an in-house system it makes sense to at least initially start by leveraging a
third-party asre system like Google ASR Microsoft speech services etc and it's
important to note that while all of these generic ASR systems have
reportedly low word error rates on generic English language about less than
6% on English voice search queries when you get into the area of noisy
environments different accents like you mentioned and uncommon terms like person
names or other proper nouns and entities the word error rate becomes
significantly higher so we found that in our dataset it goes up to almost 41 percent and so it's important to keep
this in mind in the rest of the pipeline and I'll point out some of the models in
our pipeline where we are focusing on making them robust to the sort of ASR
errors so now the first component of the
natural language processing pipeline is the domain classifier and so domain is a
broad area of unique set of knowledge or vocabulary for example sports is a
domain and whether is the domain music is the domain and so the domain classifier uses features from the
language of the query to classify an example into one of your predefined
domains so this domain classifier is a classification model so you can use
machine learning models like logistic regression a support vector machine SVM decision tree
cetera and you can also use many different language features like
character engrams word engrams different orthographic features gazetteer matches
etc and it's also important to note that using these classic models work well for
all training data set sizes but as you get very large amounts of data you can
also consider using neural network based approaches and so now to get make this a
little bit more concrete we're also going to consider a specific example as we go through the pipeline so this
example is scheduled a meeting with Janice from accounting from 11:00 a.m. to noon and aquarelle oh and so from
this impact query text we extract certain language features and the domain classifier is able to classify this as
the meetings domain over one of the other domains of expense procurement or travel then the next component of the
pipeline is the intent classifier so within each domain there's different
intents of what the user may want to do for example in the food ordering domain someone could be searching for a
restaurant by name or they could be trying to find a particular item on a menu or they could be trying to complete
an order a place to request and so each of these different intents is a another
classification model which takes in the context of the current domain as well as the language features of the query to
then classify your query into one of these predefined intents so the attend
classifier is again a classification model and you can use the same sorts of models and features for the intent
classifier but it is useful to separate out the domain and then type classification into two models two steps
of the pipeline because you're able to get have both of the models focused on
different types of features in the query and you're able to get much higher accuracy by doing it as a two-step
process rather than trying to classify across all domains and intense in a single step
and then back to our example so now that we are in the meetings domain from the
extracted features we can then classify this as a scheduled meeting intent
within that domain the next component is
the entity recognizer and the entity recognizer detects certain key words or

natural language understanding there's a concept of semantic parsing which is trying to understand the meaning of a
query based on how the tokens are related to each other so the top image
is an example of a full semantic parse but in many practical situations it can
be a high latency and cost effective to train a full semantic parser and you
often only really care about certain relation types so a very shallow form of
semantic parsing can be considered this role classifier where we're just considering the quantity type and
assigning that to the child entity of 6 or similarly if you had a query like
I'll have the 6 ounce soda instead of I'll have 6 sodas then in the first

the way entity resolution works is it's a text relevance information retrieval
based approach which matches the text of the entity from the user query against
database which contains all of the official canonical values that are possible for that entity I guess this is

resolver this is where we really have to be careful about being robust to ASR errors because entities are often the

broad categories of features that we use the first is text-based features and so
with text features we have fuzzy matching which is normalization using character engrams and weird engrams to
do fuzzy matching between the the text and the canonical forms and this takes
into account minor spelling variations as well as typos if it's a text based input we also have what we call semantic
synonym matching and so we have a predefined set of semantic synonyms that exist in our database things like pasta
with tomato sauce for spaghetti marinara and so in addition to matching textually
against the canonical values we also match against the semantic synonyms as well as common nicknames and aliases
then the second broad category is phonetic features so this is what is essential for voice based inputs since
we are using third-party ASR systems we don't have access to the phonemes
generated directly from the audio so instead we use a few different

double meta phone is a rules-based algorithmic approach which generates a
phonemes and graphing two phoneme is a neural network sequence the sequence model which generates the phonemes and

text because the same word may be trans spoken differently by different people
people may have different accents or just in different contexts it may be pronounced differently by using multiple
phonetic models we can kind of have complementary effects of trying to cover
more ground and so both of these phonetic signals can be used
to match phonetically against all the canonical values and try to correct things that are transcribed to be
textually different but phonetically similar like the two top examples in

another form of shallow semantic parsing so previously the role they were
labeling was extracting just the quantity relation type and now in this
case language parser is just extracting the relation groups of the head and the
child entities without worrying about what the relation type is so in this example a bagel with butter and worm
muffin bagel and butter are grouped together and warm and muffin are grouped
together and in used cases where you want both the grouping as well as a

call active learning and essentially what that means is that we intelligently
choose which data to select and annotate because in production raw data a raw
user logs are cheap but still annotating that data is still very expensive so we
can use different metrics like model and certainty to choose the queries that our
model is currently most uncertain about and select those ones to annotate and add back to our training data first and

generate some bootstrapped annotations and these bootstrapped annotations are sent to Mechanical Turk

update the annotations and verify that they're correct so that after this point
we have clean verified annotations that we can add back to our training data then we will automatically compute the
